12.text: The will to live life differently can start

15.text: in some of the most unusual places.

18.text: This is where I come from, Todmorden.

20.text: It's a market town in the north of England,

27.text: It used to look like this,

29.text: and now it's more like this,

32.text: with fruit and veg and herbs sprouting up all over the place.

40.text: Corner row railway, station car park,

43.text: front of a health center, people's front gardens,

47.text: and even in front of the police station. (Laughter)

62.text: We've even invented a new form of tourism.

65.text: It's called vegetable tourism, and believe it or not,

68.text: people come from all over the world to poke around in our raised beds,

72.text: even when there's not much growing. (Laughter)

79.text: And, you know, we're not doing it because we're bored. (Laughter)

83.text: We're doing it because we want to start a revolution.

88.text: We tried to answer this simple question:

89.text: Can you find a unifying language that cuts across age

92.text: and income and culture that will help people themselves

96.text: find a new way of living,

100.text: think about the resources they use differently,

107.text: And then, can we replicate those actions?

111.text: And the answer would appear to be yes,

114.text: and the language would appear to be food.

117.text: So, three and a half years ago, a few of us

119.text: sat around a kitchen table and

121.text: we just invented the whole thing. (Laughter)

127.text: We came up with a really simple game plan that we put to a public meeting.

130.text: We did not consult. We did not write a report.

135.text: And we said to that public meeting in Todmorden,

138.text: look, let's imagine that our town

142.text: a community plate, the way we live our everyday lives;

145.text: a learning plate, what we teach our kids in school

148.text: and what new skills we share amongst ourselves;

150.text: and business, what we do with the pound in our pocket

154.text: and which businesses we choose to support.

155.text: Now, let's imagine those plates agitated

161.text: If we start one of those community plates spinning,

163.text: that's really great, that really starts to empower people,

166.text: but if we can then spin that community plate

168.text: with the learning plate, and then spin it with the business plate,

171.text: we've got a real show there, we've got some action theater.

175.text: We're starting to build resilience ourselves.

178.text: We're starting to reinvent community ourselves,

182.text: and we've done it all without a flipping strategy document.

191.text: And here's the thing as well.

193.text: We've not asked anybody's permission to do this,

198.text: And we are certainly not waiting for that check

200.text: to drop through the letterbox before we start,

203.text: and most importantly of all, we are not daunted

205.text: by the sophisticated arguments that say,

207.text: "These small actions are meaningless in the face of tomorrow's problems,"

211.text: because I have seen the power of small actions,

216.text: So, back to the public meeting. (Laughter)

220.text: We put that proposition to the meeting, two seconds,

224.text: I have never, ever experienced anything like that in my life.

228.text: And it's been the same in every single room, in every town

231.text: that we've ever told our story.

233.text: People are ready and respond to the story of food.

237.text: They want positive actions they can engage in,

240.text: and in their bones, they know it's time

244.text: and invest in more kindness to each other

250.text: And since we had that meeting three and a half years ago,

253.text: it's been a heck of a roller coaster.

256.text: We started with a seed swap, really simple stuff,

259.text: and then we took an area of land, a strip on the side

261.text: of our main road, which was a dog toilet, basically,

264.text: and we turned it into a really lovely herb garden.

267.text: We took the corner of the car park in the station

269.text: that you saw, and we made vegetable beds

271.text: for everybody to share and pick from themselves.

275.text: We went to the doctors. We've just had

276.text: a 6-million-pound health center built in Todmorden,

279.text: and for some reason that I cannot comprehend,

282.text: it has been surrounded by prickly plants. (Laughter)

285.text: So we went to the doctors, said, "Would you mind us taking them up?"

288.text: They said, "Absolutely fine, provided you get planning permission

291.text: and you do it in Latin and you do it in triplicate,"

293.text: so we did — (Laughter) — and now there are fruit trees

296.text: and bushes and herbs and vegetables

302.text: And there's been lots of other examples, like the corn

304.text: that was in front of the police station,

306.text: and the old people's home that we've planted it with food

308.text: that they can pick and grow.

310.text: But it isn't just about growing,

312.text: because we all are part of this jigsaw.

314.text: It's about taking those artistic people in your community

317.text: and doing some fabulous designs in those raised beds

319.text: to explain to people what's growing there,

321.text: because there's so many people that don't really recognize

324.text: a vegetable unless it's in a bit of plastic

326.text: with a bit of an instruction packet on the top. (Laughter)

328.text: So we have some people who designed these things,

330.text: "If it looks like this, please don't pick it, but if it looks like this,

334.text: This is about sharing and investing in kindness.

337.text: And for those people that don't want to do either

339.text: of those things, maybe they can cook,

341.text: so we pick them seasonally and then we go on the street,

344.text: or in the pub, or in the church,

346.text: or wherever people are living their lives.

348.text: This is about us going to the people and saying,

350.text: "We are all part of the local food jigsaw,

353.text: we are all part of a solution."

356.text: And then, because we know we've got vegetable tourists

358.text: and we love them to bits and they're absolutely fantastic,

360.text: we thought, what could we do to give them an even better experience?

363.text: So we invented, without asking, of course,

368.text: And this is a route of exhibition gardens,

370.text: and edible towpaths, and bee-friendly sites, and the story

375.text: of pollinators, and it's a route that we designed

378.text: that takes people through the whole of our town,

380.text: past our cafes and our small shops, through our market,

384.text: not just to and fro from the supermarket,

387.text: and we're hoping that, in changing people's footfall

389.text: around our town, we're also changing their behavior.

392.text: And then there's the second plate, the learning plate.

396.text: Well, we're in partnership with a high school.

398.text: We've created a company. We are designing and building

401.text: an aquaponics unit in some land that was spare

403.text: at the back of the high school, like you do,

405.text: and now we're going to be growing fish and vegetables

409.text: and the kids are helping us build that,

412.text: and the kids are on the board, and because the community

414.text: was really keen on working with the high school,

416.text: the high school is now teaching agriculture,

419.text: and because it's teaching agriculture, we started to think,

422.text: how could we then get those kids that never had a qualification

425.text: before in their lives but are really excited about growing,

428.text: how can we give them some more experience?

429.text: So we got some land that was donated

433.text: It was really quite muddy, but in a truly incredible way,

436.text: totally voluntary-led, we have turned that

439.text: into a market garden training center,

441.text: and that is polytunnels and raised beds

444.text: and all the things you need to get the soil under your fingers

446.text: and think maybe there's a job in this for me in the future.

449.text: And because we were doing that, some local academics said,

452.text: a commercial horticulture course for you.

454.text: There's not one that we know of."

456.text: So they're doing that, and we're going to launch it later this year,

458.text: and it's all an experiment, and it's all voluntary.

461.text: And then there's the third plate,

462.text: because if you walk through an edible landscape,

464.text: and if you're learning new skills, and if you start to get

469.text: you might just want to spend more of your own money

473.text: not just veg, but meat and cheese and beer

475.text: and whatever else it might be.

477.text: But then, we're just a community group, you know.

479.text: We're just all volunteers. What could we actually do?

481.text: So we did some really simple things.

483.text: We fundraised, we got some blackboards,

485.text: we put "Incredible Edible" on the top,

486.text: we gave it every market trader that was selling locally,

488.text: and they scribbled on what they were selling in any one week.

491.text: Really popular. People congregated around it.

495.text: And then, we had a chat with the farmers, and we said,

499.text: but they didn't actually believe us, so we thought,

502.text: okay, what should we do? I know. If we can create

504.text: a campaign around one product and show them

507.text: there is local loyalty to that product,

509.text: maybe they'll change their mind and see we're serious.

511.text: So we launched a campaign -- because it just amuses me --

516.text: And what we did was we put people on our egg map.

520.text: It's a stylized map of Togmorden.

522.text: Anybody that's selling their excess eggs

524.text: at the garden gate, perfectly legally, to their neighbors,

526.text: we've stuck on there. We started with four,

529.text: and we've now got 64 on, and the result of that was

531.text: that people were then going into shops

532.text: asking for a local Todmorden egg, and the result of that

535.text: was, some farmers upped the amount of flocks they got

537.text: of free range birds, and then they went on to meat birds,

540.text: and although these are really, really small steps,

547.text: is starting to play out in a number of ways,

549.text: and we now have farmers doing cheese

551.text: and they've upped their flocks and rare breed pigs,

552.text: they're doing pasties and pies and things

554.text: that they would have never done before.

556.text: We've got increasing market stalls selling local food,

559.text: and in a survey that local students did for us, 49 percent

563.text: of all food traders in that town said that their bottom line

566.text: had increased because of what we were actually doing.

568.text: And we're just volunteers and it's only an experiment.

573.text: Now, none of this is rocket science.

575.text: It certainly is not clever, and it's not original.

578.text: But it is joined up, and it is inclusive.

582.text: This is not a movement for those people

584.text: that are going to sort themselves out anyway.

586.text: This is a movement for everyone.

589.text: We have a motto: If you eat, you're in. (Laughter)

599.text: Across age, across income, across culture.

604.text: It's been really quite a roller coaster experience,

608.text: but going back to that first question that we asked,

610.text: is it replicable? Yeah. It most certainly is replicable.

613.text: More than 30 towns in England now are spinning

618.text: Whichever way they want to do it, of their own volition,

622.text: they're trying to make their own lives differently,

624.text: and worldwide, we've got communities across America

627.text: and Japan -- it's incredible, isn't it? I mean,

629.text: America and Japan and New Zealand.

631.text: People after the earthquake in New Zealand visited us

634.text: in order to incorporate some of this public spiritedness

637.text: around local growing into the heart of Christchurch.

642.text: And none of this takes more money

645.text: and none of this demands a bureaucracy,

648.text: but it does demand that you think things differently

651.text: and you are prepared to bend budgets and work programs

654.text: in order to create that supportive framework

659.text: And there's some great ideas already in our patch.

662.text: Our local authority has decided to make everywhere

665.text: Incredible Edible, and in support of that

667.text: have decided to do two things.

669.text: First, they're going to create an asset register of spare land

672.text: that they've got, put it in a food bank so that communities

674.text: can use that wherever they live,

676.text: and they're going to underpin that with a license.

678.text: And then they've said to every single one of their workforce,

681.text: if you can, help those communities grow,

683.text: and help them to maintain their spaces.

685.text: Suddenly, we're seeing actions on the ground

687.text: from local government. We're seeing this mainstreamed.

689.text: We are responding creatively at last to what Rio demanded

694.text: of us, and there's lots more you could do.

696.text: I mean, just to list a few. One, please stop putting

698.text: prickly plants around public buildings. It's a waste of space.

702.text: (Laughter) Secondly, please create -- please, please create

705.text: edible landscapes so that our children start to walk

708.text: past their food day in, day out, on our high streets,

710.text: in our parks, wherever that might be.

713.text: Inspire local planners to put the food sites at the heart

716.text: of the town and the city plan, not relegate them

720.text: to the edges of the settlements that nobody can see.

723.text: Encourage all our schools to take this seriously.

726.text: This isn't a second class exercise.

728.text: If we want to inspire the farmers of tomorrow,

731.text: then please let us say to every school,

734.text: create a sense of purpose around the importance

738.text: to the environment, local food and soils.

741.text: Put that at the heart of your school culture,

743.text: and you will create a different generation.

746.text: There are so many things you can do, but ultimately

748.text: this is about something really simple.

754.text: an increasing recognition of the power of small actions,

759.text: we are starting, at last, to believe in ourselves again,

762.text: and to believe in our capacity, each and every one of us,

766.text: to build a different and a kinder future,

771.text: and in my book, that's incredible.
